posts.name: wesbass23
posts.cooked: Not to speak for Nelson but our team’s control layout is pretty fluid over the course of the season. We usually start out with a lot more controls in the hands of the operator and as the driver gets better and we figure out better ways to control the robot we tend to transfer more control to the driver. However we often still leave those abilities with the operator as well. This can be useful when practicing/troubleshooting outside of a match or when bringing in new drivers.

These are the controls we used at Battle at the Border, with minor variations. The Operator could reverse the direction of the intake using POV Left iirc, but the only reason it was bound to that was because there wasn’t any other button available.

3255 2021 Controls 1 960×540 151 KB 3255 2021 Controls 2 960×540 126 KB 3255 2021 Controls 3 960×540 156 KB

3255 2021 Controls 1 960×540 151 KB

3255 2021 Controls 1 960×540 151 KB

3255 2021 Controls 2 960×540 126 KB

3255 2021 Controls 2 960×540 126 KB

3255 2021 Controls 3 960×540 156 KB

3255 2021 Controls 3 960×540 156 KB

We also have a physical switchboard with 12 switches that we use to toggle different stages of our autonomous. For example, if we know that an alliance partner has a conflicting autonomous routine, we can switch off every stage other than shoot the preloaded balls and move forward. Our auto was broken at Battle at the Border though, so when we were there our switchboard was completely useless.

Our team is looking to move away from the flight stick as the operator controller, and to just use a standard gamepad. This is technically game dependent but I can’t imagine us using the flight stick for the operator next year, as there isn’t really any task that would require the granularity that the flight stick provides. We may use two flight sticks for the driver though, instead of the gamepad, because driving does actually benefit from the increased granularity.

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
The hopper gets deployed during Auto and if you’re just practicing or tuning you could just single joystick it. Resetting the hopper using one of those controls, up.

Normally the operator is handling the hopper but the shared control does let the driver retract it back in frame if some situation requires that.  You cant intake, shoot, climb, etc on the driver stick but at least you can be inside the bumpers.

Really it should just be up, but I sort of dislike having a one way control.  So mirroring all the controls there seemed to make sense.  By that I mean if you are using the controller you can both move the hopper in and out, even though really you only practically need in.  But if want to test in is working on the controller you’d have to use a different way to make the hopper go out.  Spinning the robot does, but having a proper control for the mechanism is my own preference as long as it doesn’t interfere and you have room.

posts.name: Bri
posts.cooked:
Reciting these from memory so it’s possible I’ve forgotten some info. I’ve both driven and operated this robot (this is for our 2020 bot. 2021 is basically identical but with no operator controller whatsoever)

Screenshot_20211104-025116 2048×1139 617 KB Screenshot_20211104-025132 2048×1131 682 KB

Screenshot_20211104-025116 2048×1139 617 KB

image 730×671 41.6 KB We used a 3x3 button board, I didn’t really like a xBox controller but probably should get used to it next season.

image 730×671 41.6 KB

image 730×671 41.6 KB

For driving the robot, we had two logitech attack 3s where one stick was translation and the other was rotation. The trigger on the right stick was setting the drive mode (Field oriented vs. robot) and the one on the left ran our auto shooting sequence. There was also a button for zeroing our navx if we needed it.

We gave the driver control over shooting because they will know exactly when they are lined up (we had no turret or vision) so it is a little faster that way.

posts.name: Noam Prag
posts.cooked:
Chester controls 1690×934 578 KB

Chester controls 1690×934 578 KB

Chester controls 1690×934 578 KB

In Orbit (1690), we only use one driver, which simplifies communication and gives us more flexibility on the field. We use a lot of automation to help him do everything. For example, pressing triangle activates Autodrive mode, which sends the robot on the optimal path to the top of the Target Zone, aims and shoots as soon as everything’s ready. In regular operation the driver only presses 4 buttons (besides the joysticks for actually moving around) - Feeder, Travel, Autodrive, and Intake modes. The rest are backups in case something goes wrong. The operator (or as we call it - “Commander”) is free to check out the field and acts as a secondary coach. He can also help analyze and fix issues through the laptop(for example, adding percent values to shots mid game if we’re missing).

posts.name: Allison Conrad
posts.cooked:
Not so much posting our controls as I am posting how we document them

I plan to formally release this publicly a bit closer to season, but here’s a preview of what I’ve been working on to document team button layouts. It’s an excel sheet with a photoshopped image in the middle, and each button has a dropdown of all the robot functions so you can quickly make nice looking (and cloud sync’d) button layouts. I’ve been using a version of this to document our PDP layouts the past few seasons, which has really helped our electrical and programming students stay on the same page as to what CAN ID’s are, what motor controllers are in use, ect.

posts.name: Noam Prag
posts.cooked:
Hey, thanks for the more specific questions on these topics. The reason for choosing the PS5 controller over Xbox and other is the fact that our driver just prefers this controller. We had experience with PS4 and Xbox One controllers and just found the PS5 to be the most comfortable and smooth. One disadvantage of ps controllers is that we didn’t manage to get the “rumble” function to work (we did do it with the Xbox).

Regarding the “Autodrive” algorithm, in order to understand it we must talk first about our “Pose Tracker”. The “Pose Tracker” is the part of the code that finds the robot’s position in real time, using various sensors. The sensors being used are the swerve’s encoders, gyro, Limelight, and our custom vision (made with Raspberry PI). Some of these sensors are absolute, meaning they give absolute position (image processing for example). Other sensors are relative, meaning the data they give is relative to past position (swerve encoders for example). The Pose Tracker we wrote combines all these sensors in a way that takes into account all the properties of each sensor, and yields a the robot’s pose accurately (which includes position, velocity, acceleration, heading, angular velocity and angular acceleration).

The “Autodrive” algorithm takes the pose from the pose tracker and finds the optimal angular velocity and translation velocity to the target in each given moment. The velocity and angular velocity are calculated using forward and inverse kinematics. The idea is to find, for a given moment, the acceleration and the velocity which would get the robot exactly to the final position with 0 velocity taking into account its mass, inertia, current velocity and angular velocity, etc … So, for example, when the driver presses the “triangle” the shooter opens, accelerates, the robot auto-drives to the triangle safe zone, when all conditions for shooting are met – shooting starts automatically.

The robot’s “modes” are a set of states the robot could be in during a match. Each mode corresponds to a different action. In all times, the “State Manager” collects inputs from the driver, as well as data from sensors. Then, a “reducer” function is called, which determines the next state of the robot according to inputs and other logic.

When the robot’s state is determined it is passed down to the subsystems. Each subsystem accepts a robot state and determines its own internal state, using similar logic. Then, each subsystems sets the output to the motors and pistons according to its current state. For example in “intake state” – one button from the driver – the robot closes the shooter, opens the intake, runs the intake motor at the right speed according to the robot velocity, rotates the spindexer in a “serialize” motion profile, runs the “de-jammig” wheel in the right direction and velocity, runs the “transfer belts” in reverse so no balls enter the shooter, etc… all this and more happens automatically with one button.

Furthermore, while modes are automations for robot actions, we could automate it even more with automatic mode switching. For example, in a “shoot” state, we could detect that all the balls on the robot were shot, and automatically switch to an intake state.

This all idea of the “state machine” could be thought of as a complicated nested MVC, where the “model” is the current state, the “view” is the output to motors, piston, LEDs, etc. and the controller is the “State Manager” that takes inputs from the driver and from sensors, and uses some logic to determine the next state.

posts.name: Noam Prag
posts.cooked:
Autodrive demonstration

This is a brief video from the time we developed the autodrive, the performance then was not as smooth as later versions, but it shows the concept. The long time it takes to shoot in the video is because we load only 2 balls, and it takes the spindexer some time to reach to a ball in case the shoot started in an empty spot.

To be clear here, this drive is not an autonomous drive with trajectory known in advance. This is a demo of autodrive between two points - feeder/ safezone. The algorithm calculates in real time the path from any point to any point on the field. So in real matches, the driver just collects power cells and presses autodrive from any random location.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
very very sweet looking document.

Software guy popping in here: It would take some assumptions, but being able to auto-generate code based on the selections in that document would be radical.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Others may disagree, but I really like this concept, and am thrilled to see it executed well!

Did it see usage on a real field yet, not just for at-home practice? If so, how was driver preference to using it over manual control?

Also @mdurrani834 -

autointake

looks shiny! Can you describe the system? What was auto about it, how did it decide to do intaking?

Looking at above it’s not that shiny and probably named pretty badly

It is just a sequential command group that repeatedly runs our “run Conveyor Sensor” command which just runs out intake and spaces out conveyor balls automatically ( we have a linear ball tube with one sensor. Its nice because it will only run 5 times, we will never take in too many balls or keep track ourselves.
